lines.text: Enter MARK ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, IRAS, ALEXAS, with others

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: He will not fight with me, Domitius.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Why should he not

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune, He is twenty men to one.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Tomorrow, soldier, By sea and land Ill fight: or I will live, Or bathe my dying honour in the blood Shall make it live again. Woot thou fight well

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Ill strike, and cry Take all.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Well said come on. Call forth my household servants: lets tonight Be bounteous at our meal. Give me thy hand, Thou hast been rightly honestso hast thou Thou,and thou,and thou:you have served me well, And kings have been your fellows.
Enter three or four Servitors

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: [Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  What means this

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside to CLEOPATRA]  Tis one of those odd tricks which sorrow shoots Out of the mind.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: And thou art honest too. I wish I could be made so many men, And all of you clappd up together in An Antony, that I might do you service So good as you have done.

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: The gods forbid!

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight: Scant not my cups and make as much of me As when mine empire was your fellow too, And sufferd my command.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: [Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  What does he mean

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside to CLEOPATRA]  To make his followers weep.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Tend me tonight May be it is the period of your duty: Haply you shall not see me more or if, A mangled shadow: perchance tomorrow Youll serve another master. I look on you As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends, I turn you not away but, like a master Married to your good service, stay till death: Tend me tonight two hours, I ask no more, And the gods yield you fort!

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: What mean you, sir, To give them this discomfort Look, they weep And I, an ass, am onioneyed: for shame, Transform us not to women.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Ho, ho, ho! Now the witch take me, if I meant it thus! Grace grow where those drops fall! My hearty friends, You take me in too dolorous a sense For I spake to you for your comfort did desire you To burn this night with torches: know, my hearts, I hope well of tomorrow and will lead you Where rather Ill expect victorious life Than death and honour. Lets to supper, come, And drown consideration.
Exeunt
